facts.text: Writ Petition No. 65 of 1959 filed in Original Jurisdiction under Article 32 of the Constitution for enforcement of Fundamental Rights.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Writ Petition No. 65 of 1959. Petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for enforcement of Fundamental Rights.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on April 10, 1961 by DAS GUPTA, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. April 10. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by DAS GUPTA, J.-This application under Art. 32 of the Constitution is for the protection of fundamental rights under Art. 19 1  f  and  g , Art. 31 and Art. 14 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Application under Article 32 for protection of fundamental rights under Articles 19(1)(f) and (g), 31 and 14.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by DAS GUPTA, J.-This application under Art. 32 of the Constitution is for the protection of fundamental rights under Art. 19 1  f  and  g , Art. 31 and Art. 14 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Second and third applicants are merchants who used to import considerable quantities of glass chatons up to 1957.

anchor.surface_text: The second and the third applicants are merchants who used to import companysiderable quantities of glass chatons upto 1957.

facts.text: First applicant is an Association of merchants, some of whom were importers and some actual users of glass chatons.

anchor.surface_text: The first applicant is an Association of merchants, some of whom were importers and some the actual users of glass chatons.

facts.text: Glass chatons form an important part of raw materials for manufacture of glass bangles and other similar articles.

anchor.surface_text: Import of glass chatons-which form an important part of the raw materials for the manufacture of glass bangles and other similar articles of wear companyld, be made only on licences granted by licensing authorities.

facts.text: Imports regulated since 1955 by Imports Control Order, 1955 made under sections 3 and 4-A of Import and Export Control Act, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: Since 1955 the matter has been regu- lated by the Imports  Control  Order, 1955. This Order which was made by the Central Government in exercise of powers companyferred by sections 3 and 4-A of the Import and Export Control Act, 1947, prohibited the import of a large number of goods including inter alia glass chatons, except under and, in accordance with a licence, granted on application by the licensing authorities under the Act.

facts.text: Import policy for glass chatons from January 1957 to end of March 1958 was total prohibition.

anchor.surface_text: The policy as regards the import of glass chatons for the period January, 1957 to the end of March, 1958 was that the import was totally prohibited.

facts.text: From April 1958, import of glass chatons permitted only under Export Promotion Scheme.

anchor.surface_text: Since April 1958, the policy as laid down is that import was permitted only under the Export Promotion Scheme.

facts.text: No application made by second or third applicants or other merchants for import of glass chatons in 1957 or thereafter; no licences issued to them.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that in view of this policy statement numberapplication was made at all by the second or third applicants or other merchants for the import of glass chatons, in 1957 or thereafter and numberlicence was issued to them.

facts.text: Licences issued to State Trading Corporation for import of glass chatons worth five lakhs rupees for April-September 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Licences were however issued in favour of the State Trading Corporation, for the import of glass chatons of the value of five lakhs of Rupees, for the period April- September, 1958,

facts.text: Licences issued to State Trading Corporation for import of glass chatons worth Rs. 1,25,000 for October 1958 to March 1959.

anchor.surface_text: and again, for the import of these goods of the value of Rs. 1,25,000 for the period October, 1958 to March, 1959.

facts.text: Present application made on April 27, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: The present application was made on April 27, 1959.

facts.text: Petitioners prayed that respondents 1 and 2 forbear from giving preference to State Trading Corporation in grant of permits.

anchor.surface_text: The prayer is that respondents 1 and 2-i.e., the Union of India and the Chief Controller, Imports, should be directed  i  to forbear from giving the State Trading Corporation any preference over the petitioners, in the grant of permits,

facts.text: Petitioners prayed not to create monopoly in favour of State Trading Corporation.

anchor.surface_text: ii  number to create a monopoly in favour of the State Trading Corporation,

facts.text: Petitioners prayed to cancel import permits already granted to State Trading Corporation.

anchor.surface_text: iii  to cancel the import permits already granted in favour of respondent No. 3--the State Trading Corporation

facts.text: Periods of import permits granted to State Trading Corporation have expired.

anchor.surface_text: It has to be mentioned at once that the periods of the import permit already granted as referred to in the petition has already expired and companysequently, the last two prayers mentioned above cannot possibly be granted.

facts.text: No application by second and third applicants or members of first applicant for import licences.

anchor.surface_text: There was numberapplication at all by the second and the third applicants, or any of the merchants who form the association, the 1st appellant for the issue of any import licences

facts.text: No scheme to issue fresh licences in favour of State Trading Corporation.

anchor.surface_text: Nor is there, as far as can be made out, any scheme to issue fresh licences in favour of the State Trading Corporation so that apart from what has already happened there is numberquestion of any future action to create a monopoly in favour of the State Trading Corporation.

facts.text: Petitioners challenge Para 6(h) of Imports Control Order, 1955 as void under Articles 19(1)(f)(g), 31.

anchor.surface_text: Learned Counsel has argued that this provision in clause  h  of Para. 6 is void being in companytravention of Art. 19 1  f  and  g , and Art. 31 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Petitioners challenge section 3 of Imports and Exports Control Act, 1947 to extent it permits Para 6(h).

anchor.surface_text: He also urged that to the extent s. 3 of the Imports and Exports Control Act, 1947, permits the Central Government to make an order as in Para. 6 h  s. 3 itself is bad.

facts.text: Petitioners did not apply for licences under Export Promotion Scheme.

anchor.surface_text: It is clear however that though it was open to these petitioners to apply for licences under the Export Promotion Scheme they made numberapplication for licence thereunder.

facts.text: Court holds petitioners not entitled to any relief under Article 32.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, we are of opinion that the petitioners are number entitled Iwo any relief under Art. 32 of the Con. stitution.

anchor.surface_text: Para. 6 is void being in contravention of Art. 19 1 f and g , and Art. 31 of the Constitution.

holdings.text: The attack on the validity of Para. 6(h) of the Imports Control Order, 1955 under Articles 19(1)(f) and (g) fails.

anchor.surface_text: The attack on the validity of Para. 6 h of the Imports Control Order, 1955, therefore, fails.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Canalization of imports through selected agencies is presumed to be in the interests of the general public unless clearly shown otherwise; refusal of licences under Para 6(h) is necessary to implement such policy and thus a reasonable restriction under Art. 19(6).

holdings.text: The provision in Para. 6(h) does not contravene Article 31.

anchor.surface_text: The attack on this provision in Para. 6 h of the order that it contravenes Art. 31 is not even plausible.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Refusal of licence does not amount to acquisition of property or right to trade under Art. 31; granting to selected agencies does not transfer rights from applicants.

holdings.text: Section 3 of the Imports and Exports Control Act, 1947 is not bad to the extent it permits orders like Para. 6(h).

anchor.surface_text: The contention that s. 3 of the Imports and Exports Control Act, 1947, is bad to the extent that it permits the government to make an order as in Para. 6 h of the Imports Control Order, 1955, consequently also fails.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Validity follows from upholding Para 6(h); empowers reasonable restrictions.

holdings.text: Canalization through special agencies or channels is in the interests of the general public, presumed unless contrary clearly shown.

anchor.surface_text: the Court would proceed on the assumption that that decision is in the interests of the general public unless the contrary. is clearly shown.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Import policy integral to economic policy; courts defer due to complexity, place heavy burden on challenger to disprove public interest.

holdings.text: No denial of equal protection under Art. 14 as petitioners did not apply for licences.

anchor.surface_text: There is no scope therefore for the argument that they have been discriminated against.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No application made under Export Promotion Scheme, so no basis for comparison or discrimination claim.

holdings.text: Petitioners not entitled to any relief under Art. 32.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, we are of opinion that the petitioners are not entitled to any relief under Art. 32 of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No live grievance (permits expired, no applications, no future monopoly); challenges to provisions fail.

holdings.text: Selection of particular channel or agency for canalization may be challenged under Art. 14 if it infringes equality.

anchor.surface_text: the selection of the particular channel or agency decided upon in implementing the decision of canalisation may well be Challenged on the ground that it infringes Art. 14 of the Constitution or some other fundamental rights.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinction between policy decision to canalize (hard to challenge) and implementation choice of agency (subject to Art. 14 scrutiny); obiter as no challenge raised here.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, we are of opinion that the petitioners are number entitled Iwo any relief under Art. 32 of the Con. stitution.

outcome.relief_summary: Petitioners not entitled to any relief under Art. 32 of the Constitution
